title: Ex-spouse got awarded house in divorce and had to pay for it, but got foreclosed how will it impact me?
question: In 2009, we divorced. I asked to have my name taking off the mortgage but my husband couldn't refinance. My name stayed in the mortgage and title. My husband got awarded the house and had to make the payment. I had to move out with my daughter. I couldn't contact my ex has i had two restraining order against him for domestic violence. I recently got a paper, informing me that, not only he lost the house and it got sold in foreclosure (trustee sale) but he also filed for bankruptcy (chap.7). What can I do?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Divorce and foreclosure,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Domestic violence and criminal charges,Restraining order and criminal defense,Tax return,Mortgage debt,Tax law
answers: Others have talked about the potential tax consequences. Additionally, there is some discussion of the fact that you may be liable to a 2nd mortgage if you have one and it was one that was obtained after the purchase of the house. There is a third problem. If there are debts from the marriage, you can be liable for them even if the dissolution order said he had to pay the debts. The family law order does not bind the creditor. You may have the right to "indemnification" from your ex-spouse. You should have an attorney at least look at your situation and advise you accordingly.

1. Assuming this home was in California and only the first priority loan has your name on it, then the lender has chosen a nonjudicial foreclosure and cannot pursue you for a deficiency.
2. You should consult a tax professional regarding the tax issues because there are several facts not present in your statement that could change the answer (e.g., are you insolvent, what is your tax basis in the home, exactly how many days in the last five years you resided at the home, etc.).
3. You didn't ask, but the foreclosure probably will show up on your credit report. There isn't much you can do about that now.

No, you will not be sued by the lender since they cannot pursue you for any deficiency. I'm not so sure about the 1099 however. If your husband's discharge of the mortgage debt took place in 2013, then I do not believe IRS Form 982 box 1e would apply. I also don't think box 1e would apply since the house was not your principal residence at the time the debt was discharged, and per your facts had not been your residence since 2009. Likewise, I do not believe you could check box 1a since it was not YOUR Title 11 case in which the discharge occured. You might have an insolvency argument (box 1b) but you can't check that box if there was a Title 11 case in which the debt was discharged. I think you might be in kind of a Catch-22. So, I think I would defer to a tax specialist on this one, as far as any potential tax liability on the forgiven / discharged debt.

Hopefully you were not a co-debtor on a HELOC as well as the mortgage; but a foreclosing lender cannot come after you for any deficiency. You will not have a tax liability ... file IRS Form 982 with your tax return and check box 1e.

This will go on your credit record because your name was on the mortgage. Most first mortgageholder's do not file suit for the deficiency. Talk with your tax-preparer about the any tax liability. Probably won't be any.
